node.title: The rate of cancer cases in Victoria has dropped massively in the past two years, but experts say it's not good news
node.alt: Woman wearing a pink shirt, holding a glass of water, looking out her window.
node.description: Health experts fear there are thousands of Australians who are unaware they have cancer due to COVID-19 lockdowns, with new data showing the number of detected cancer cases during the pandemic is way down.
node.content:
["Health experts say there is evidence that COVID-19 lockdowns have left thousands of cancer\u00a0cases undiagnosed, with new data showing the number of detected cases down during the pandemic.\u00a0", "It has prompted a warning that the unintended health impacts of COVID-19 will linger for months, or even years.", "A Victorian Health Department report obtained by 7.30 shows that between April and July last year, there was a drop of 37 per cent\u00a0in the number of detected breast cancer cases, and a 23 per cent\u00a0drop in detected bowel cancer cases compared to the three years prior.", "Estimates for this year show a similar pattern, and Professor Sue Evans, whose team at the Victorian Cancer Council prepared the report, told 7.30\u00a0the data showing a fall in cancer cases is far from good news, and instead indicates many people are simply unaware they have the disease.", "Professor Evans\u00a0said there are concerns\u00a0those people could present with more advanced cancer in the months and years ahead.", "The figures from Victoria are most illustrative of the problem, as the state experienced the longest lockdown in the country \u2014 and the world.", "Last year\u00a07.30 revealed federal government data that showed\u00a0cancer tests had fallen during the first March-April 2020 lockdown.", "The new figures show this has translated to a drop in actual cancers being diagnosed.", "
'Difference between life or death'
", "During that initial\u00a0lockdown, 46-year-old Honnie Strachan noticed an ulcer on her tongue.", "She had started to work from her home in the Victorian town of Ballarat, more than an hour's drive from her GP in the Melbourne CBD, where she normally worked, so she delayed getting the ulcer checked by a doctor.\u00a0", "", "
Honnie Strachan was reluctant to go to a doctor during last year's lockdown when an ulcer appeared on her tongue.\u00a0(ABC News: Nadia Daly)
", "\"I just had fear at that time that exposing myself to COVID just didn't seem like a positive thing to do. So I guess I held on a little bit longer than I should have to go and see someone,\" she said.\u00a0", "Several months later, in September 2020, she finally went to a GP in her town.", "\"They gave me a referral to see an ear, nose and throat surgeon,\" she said.", "\"I went and saw him and he had a look, and pretty much immediately told me that he thought that it was cancerous \u2013 it was tongue cancer.\"", "Ms Strachan was rushed straight into surgery where half her tongue was removed and replaced with flesh from her forearm.", "\"I just thought at that time, 'Well, OK,\u00a0I may not be able to speak very well. I may not be able to work anymore. And will I survive, ultimately?'", "She spent weeks alone in hospital recovering, learning to eat and speak again with her new tongue.", "\"Since this experience, I've put my health first and everything else fits around [it] rather than it being the other way around,\" Ms Strachan said.", "She is urging everyone to \"listen to your body \u2026\u00a0make your health priority number one\".", "\"It could mean the difference between life or death for you,\" she said.", "
'Prioritise your health'
", "Similar trends are emerging in Sydney after its recent lockdown, where routine breast screening was temporarily suspended.", "\"We have seen a reduction in cancer cases,\" breast cancer surgeon Sanjay\u00a0Warrier said.", "\"And this reflects, essentially being in the middle of a pandemic strains on the system, and ultimately, a reduction in overall cancer diagnoses.\"", "", "
Breast cancer surgeon\u00a0Sanjay Warrier believes there may\u00a0be a spike in the diagnoses of breast cancer and other diseases next year.(ABC News: Tom Hancock)
", "Associate Professor Warrier\u00a0provided data to 7.30 showing a notable rise in more advanced breast cancers in his patients a year after Sydney's early 2020 lockdown.", "He says it is likely the same trend will occur after the recent lockdown, and said the impact could be felt for some time.", "\"I do believe that we may see an increase in advanced cases with time in the next year. And that's a reflection of COVID-19.", "\"And that will be both in breast [cancer] and in other diseases as well.", "\"It is important to prioritise your health \u2026 and we would really urge you, if you've got any symptoms, to see a GP.", "\"If you are due for screening, please come and get your screening done.\"", "Similar trends have also been noted overseas.", "Experts told 7.30 the reasons cancer diagnoses fall in lockdowns is likely due to the closure of some screening services, the strain on the health system, as well as people's reluctance to get symptoms assessed by a doctor due to fear of catching COVID-19.\u00a0", "
Battling cancer during COVID-19
", "In Sydney's Sutherland Shire, 53-year-old Melissa Blythe has enjoyed getting back into bushwalking with her friends since recovering from a cancer that was diagnosed in the midst of the pandemic last year.", "", "
Melissa Blythe says she regrets delaying her mammogram.(ABC News: Elena De Bruijne)
", "She had been due for a mammogram at BreastScreen, a government-run service,\u00a0in May last year.\u00a0But Ms Blythe said she was unable to get an appointment as it had just reopened after Sydney's lockdown and women who had missed appointments were given priority.", "\"I waited a couple of months, I checked my breasts again, and everything felt normal. And I thought, 'Oh, I probably should go and have a mammogram',\" she said.", "She made an appointment but said she cancelled when she became nervous about rising COVID cases.", "\"I later regretted that,\" she said.", "In September\u00a02020, Ms Blythe felt a lump, and eventually went to get tested.", "\"The ultrasound and the mammogram was showing a mass of about 4 centimetres,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
Melissa Blythe was diagnosed with triple-negative breast cancer.(Supplied)
", "She was told it was cancer and it had spread to her lymph nodes.", "\"Not only was it breast cancer, but it was triple-negative breast cancer, which is a less common type of breast cancer,\" she said.", "\"It's the most aggressive type of breast cancer\u00a0and it's the hardest to treat. So that was just a shock to hear that.", "\"I should have gone as soon as I possibly could have once BreastScreen reopened.\"", "Ms Blythe has one simple message for anyone with symptoms they are delaying getting assessed by a doctor.", "\"I wish I'd gone and had my mammogram that three months earlier, even two months earlier, because maybe the cancer would have been smaller,\" she told 7.30.\u00a0", "\"You don't ever know if you're going to be the one in seven Australian women who are diagnosed with breast cancer. But I had been checking my breasts, I haven't got a real family history.", "\"I didn't think it would be me. But it was.\"", "Watch this story on 7.30 tonight on ABC TV and iview.", "", "
How to take a rapid antigen test
"]
